books.title: The Power Broker
books.author: Robert Caro
books.found: Bought it at Strand bookstore after a gentleman told me it's an amazing book. He wasn't wrong
books.notes: I will do a full review some day, but this is one of the greatest books I have ever read. It has taught more more about power structures, ambition, and being human more than anything else. This book looks fat, but it reads easy.

books.title: War and Peace
books.author: Leo Tolstoy
books.found: Bought it at a second hand store, Feldman's, in Menlo Park. It's a beautiful hardbound.
books.notes: Kept it on the shelf so people think I am smart.

books.title: A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again
books.author: David Foster Wallace
books.found: Bought it at a second hand store (Feldman's) in Menlo Park, for something like $7. Had to buy it.
books.notes: I have read the titular essay, and it goes hard. David Foster Wallace's non-fiction is a touch to pessimistic, but I love it none the less. This is water indeed.

books.title: Grit
books.author: Angela Duckworth
books.found: My wife got this for free, when she helped organize Product Con NYC 2023
books.notes: My wife's book. The book title and cover are too cheesy for me to read (as of now)

books.title: The Case for Climate Capitalism
books.author: Tom Rand
books.found: At a climate conference I volunteered for when I was at grad school.
books.notes: Haven't read it. Doesn't interest me too much, I am solid on the basic premise I guess.

books.title: Same as Ever
books.author: Morgan Housel
books.found: Bought it at the Bengaluru Airport. A classic airport book.
books.notes: A set of short essays. Good for a quick, if somewhat mindless read. If you have read as many non-fiction books as I have, you will probably be familiar with a big chunk of these anecdotes already.

books.title: The Little Prince
books.author: Antoine de Saint‑Exupéry
books.found: Bought it in Bangalore I think. At an Om Bookstore in Phoneix Market City (if memory serves me correctly)
books.notes: One of my favourite books. Full of whimsy. Everyone should read this. Especially adults.

books.title: Masala Lab
books.author: Krish Ashok
books.found: Stole it from my brother.
books.notes: Haven't read it. From what I hear, like a Indian Kenji Lopez-Alt. But my brother says the books has a few factual inaccuracies, that put into question the other parts of the book. And the author comes across as overly smug. But ask my brother for more information on this.

books.title: The Product‑Led Organization
books.author: Todd Olson
books.found: My wife got this for free, when she helped organize Product Con NYC 2023
books.notes: There is no way I am reading this.

books.title: Ask a Native New Yorker
books.author: Jake Dobkin
books.found: My wife bought it at the Chelsea Market. I thought it was overpriced. She moved to New York and wanted to be a New Yorker.
books.notes: It's not very good.

books.title: Educated
books.author: Tara Westover
books.found: Bought it from Strand, my wife's book.
books.notes: Haven't read it, but she loved it.

books.title: Deep Work
books.author: Cal Newport
books.found: Bought it from Flipkart.
books.notes: It got me on the productivity grindset during covid. I get that this book gets meme'd a lot as a part of the tech bro essentials, but it's actually pretty good.

books.title: The Messy Middle
books.author: Scott Belsky
books.found: Bought it at a good will for $5. I once met Scott Belsky, so I thought I should buy this.
books.notes: Haven't fully read it. From the parts I read, I don't think I will learn anything new, but could be good for a skim.

books.title: Atomic Habits
books.author: James Clear
books.found: Bought from Flipkart. Bought it with Deep Work.
books.notes: Meme this book all you want, but it's straight up goated if you want to change your habits. Super practical, and minimal fluff (if you skip the anecdotes)

books.title: All the Light We Cannot See
books.author: Anthony Doerr
books.found: My wife's friend gifted this book to her.
books.notes: Neither she, nor I have read this. Looks a little sad.

books.title: The Amazing Maurice and His Educated Rodents
books.author: Terry Pratchett
books.found: Bought it at Feldman's in Menlo Park.
books.notes: I had actually bought it for my wife, because she likes fantasy. She didn't touch this book, because she doesn't like rats. I told her this book is about mice, but she wouldn't budge.

books.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
books.author: Gabriel García Márquez
books.found: Stooped from someone moving out.
books.notes: Heard it's a certified hood classic, yet to read.

books.title: The Geography of Thought
books.author: Richard E. Nisbett
books.found: Parents gifted this to me on my 27th birthday.
books.notes: Yet to read, premise looks interesting.

books.title: Debt: The First 5,000 Years
books.author: David Graeber
books.found: Parents gifted this to me on my 27th birthday.
books.notes: I like debt, so I would probably like this book I guess. I hear the book is a bit too critical of debt though. I have to read to find out.

books.title: Richard Castle's Unholy Storm (A Derrick Storm Graphic Novel)
books.author: Richard Castle
books.found: My wife's friend gifted this book to her.
books.notes: My wife and I saw Castle (season 1 to season 7) while eating dinner and got into it. My wife's friend found out and gave this book. The art style is really fun. The plot is pretty basic. My wife and I read this together in one sitting. It felt like we saw a weird episdoe of Castle, but without Castle.

books.title: Brave New World
books.author: Aldous Huxley
books.found: Stooped from someone moving out.
books.notes: Heard it's a certified hood classic, yet to read.

books.title: Outlive
books.author: Peter Attia, MD
books.found: Bought from Flipkart
books.notes: An excellent book â€“ it really got me into health. I take it super seriously now, and the science is quite interesting. I got a dexa scan, and a whole bunch of tests done after this. I recommend quite literally everyone to read this book. Skim the science if you want to, but read the other 'practical' parts

books.title: On Writing Well
books.author: William Zinsser
books.found: Bought from Amazon in India I think.
books.notes: It's a really good book on how to write well. Very non-fiction oriented. I enjoyed reading it. Very practical. If you are interested in writing a bit better, and open to a more academic view, this is a great book.

books.title: Fooled by Randomness
books.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
books.found: Bought it from a book lending startup that went bankrupt in Bangalore.
books.notes: It's good, but I'd just read antifragile instead.

books.title: Antifragile
books.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
books.found: I forget where I bought it.
books.notes: Goated book, everyone should read it. One of the rare books that changed me in a deep way. See my review.

books.title: The Black Swan
books.author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
books.found: I forget where I bought it.
books.notes: Good book, but just read antifragile instead.

books.title: Getting to Yes
books.author: Roger Fisher, William Ury, Bruce Patton

books.title: Don't Sweat the Small Stuff ... and It's All Small Stuff
books.author: Richard Carlson

books.title: Fooling Some of the People All of the Time
books.author: David Einhorn

books.title: How to Read a Book
books.author: Mortimer J. Adler & Charles Van Doren

books.title: Stuff Every Beer Snob Should Know
books.author: Ellen Goldstein

books.title: Secret Ingredients: The New Yorker Book of Food and Drink
books.author: David Remnick (ed.)

books.title: Build: An Unorthodox Guide to Making Things Worth Making
books.author: Tony Fadell

books.title: The Big Bull of Dalal Street
books.author: Neil Borate, Aprajita Sharma & Aditya Kondawar

books.title: The Things You Can See Only When You Slow Down
books.author: Haemin Sunim

books.title: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance
books.author: Robert M. Pirsig

books.title: The Heart of the Buddha’s Teaching
books.author: Thich Nhat Hanh

books.title: What Are You Doing With Your Life?
books.author: J. Krishnamurti
